Harvey Pekar.Action: Stands over his sleeping wife, calling her gently and seeking reassurance in a moment of vulnerability.
Speaks deliriously about his own existence, demonstrating confusion and distress without lashing out or blaming others.
Collapses silently, requiring care from his wife who responds with alarm and affection.
Responds to teasing by asserting he is just a kid from the neighborhood
Expresses frustration by calling others 'stoopid' and walking off
Frustrates himself and gives up on trying to explain who he is to others, calling them stupid.
Grows up and continues a routine, modest lifestyle, working a regular job and performing everyday tasks without notable success or skill.
Fixes a rip in his coat with Elmer's Glue.
Reflects on his life as going nowhere despite being scholarly and making a comics career out of it.
Lives in poor neighborhoods and holds low-quality jobs, involved in a second disastrous marriage.
Describes himself as doing the film work 'for the dough' and is irritable and contrary during recording.
Reacts to his wife's reprimands by rolling his eyes and showing annoyance rather than warmth or understanding.
Acknowledges his difficulties with relationships, showing vulnerability and self-awareness.
Admits to marrying quickly before others can 'know the real me,' indicating a hesitancy or fear of intimacy rather than open warmth.
Rants to the doctor about his failing marriage and fears his wife will forget who he really is.
Complains about his own shortcomings and marriage woes without blaming others outright.
Sheepishly grabs his throat when his voice cracks, nervously reacts to doctor's warnings.
Walks home alone, dejected, barely acknowledges a friendly acquaintance Toby and declines invitation.
Initially panics thinking he has cancer but then calms down and agrees to follow doctor's orders to rest his voice.
Raises his voice loudly despite doctor's warning, causing his voice to crack and risking permanent damage.
Responds to Toby's concern with minimal engagement and continues on his way instead of socializing or seeking support.
Eavesdrops on two women arguing and feels jealous of their ability to speak another language, but does not engage or act hostile; is startled and quietly moves on when noticed.
Passes kids playing and is momentarily wistful but tolerates their playful snowball attack without anger.
Feels dejected and paranoid about his own troubles, comparing them to greater global suffering with some humility.
Trails his wife Lana, trying to reason and asking her to wait and listen to him despite his physical inability to speak
Shows frustration and pain loudly when Lana announces she is leaving
Works at his file clerk job methodically by organizing and shelving files despite being mentally distracted.
Is mentally in a daze and distracted, not fully aware of his surroundings (e.g., doesn't hear the nurse thank him).
Demonstrates some intellectual competence by correctly identifying the origin and meaning of the poem quoted by Mr. Boats.
Shows emotional preoccupation and possible lack of focus on work due to personal feelings about Lana.
Defends rock music as having some good qualities despite Mr. Boats' criticism.
Shakes his head calmly at Mr. Boats' unfriendly accusations about keeping good records at home.
Explains what the A.M.-F.M. radio earmuffs are and offers a balanced opinion on rock music, showing understanding and some knowledge.
Does not offer or bring any Nat 'King' Cole records to Mr. Boats when requested.
Shakes head passively without defending his actions or challenging Mr. Boats' accusations about selling junk instead of good music.
Shows his prodigious and well-organized record collection, recounts starting writing jazz reviews and articles, and engages knowledgeably in a niche interest.
Haggles over a quarter price for a record with a lamination crack, showing frugality but some practical judgment.
Acknowledges living on a government wage and being tight with money, which may limit his financial confidence but reflects realism.
Shows genuine interest in meeting Bob Crumb, engages enthusiastically with his comic book novel, praises his work sincerely.
Continues to pursue conversation despite Crumb's lack of reciprocal enthusiasm.
Unselfconsciously accepts Crumb's unflattering caricature and laughs it off.
Spends time with Crumb enjoying shared interests like records and comics.
Remains alone and isolated after Crumb gradually leaves the room and social circle.
Engages Crumb in conversation, encourages and acknowledges his achievements without envy or offense.
Nods in agreement and is not offended by Crumb's self-deprecating remarks.
Expresses frustration quietly after dropping files but does not lash out or blame others.
Chooses to stand behind the Old Jewish Lady in the checkout line despite anticipating a long wait.
Rolls his eyes and stamps his foot impatiently while waiting for the price check.
Rants about the Old Jewish Lady’s behavior being frustrating but acknowledges his cultural connection and attempts to explain his feelings sincerely.
Abandons grocery cart suddenly and runs out of supermarket motivated by an odd notion to pursue his passion.
Works diligently all night on his comic project, showing dedication and sincerity to his craft.
Ponders the scene of the unsightly workers and their conversation without judgment, focusing on his creative work.
Nervously talks to Crumb about his ideas in a hesitant, sincere manner.
Does not engage with or comment on the workers' negative remarks about intelligence.
Takes the initiative to write unique comic book stories inspired by his reflections and readings, showing creative thinking and motivation.
Appears tense and nervous when presenting ideas to Crumb, speaking in a weak voice.
Proudly shows off his published comic book featuring his stories, confidently acknowledging his role as the writer despite not drawing the art.
Gives a somewhat dismissive response to a compliment by downplaying his own work, saying 'I don't go in for that macho crap.'
Hangs with the guys but doesn't engage, seems to be observing more than interacting.
Sits alone in his cubicle, posture miserable, rubbing temples in anguish.
Jokes about Sister Mary Fred becoming a nun because she couldn't get a guy, dismisses Toby's spiritual beliefs, and mocks the idea of a higher calling.
Calls after Toby asking if he seems depressed, showing some concern or awareness about his affect.
Engages politely with the counter girl, places his order without complaint.
Responds to Alice Quinn with casual recognition and recalls shared classes.
Honestly admits his academic struggles and personal difficulties.
Shares personal life challenges openly, showing vulnerability to Alice.
Stares at Alice's wedding ring with a dropped face, indicating possible envy or sadness.
Engages in a friendly, sincere conversation with Alice, showing interest in her favorites and sharing his thoughts.
Accepts Alice's offer for a lift politely but chooses to walk, expressing a subtle vulnerability by looking down sadly.
Responds to Alice's invitation for dinner with gratitude, admits his insecurity about dating, and expresses hope in a self-deprecating but honest way.
Reflects deeply on life, shows vulnerability and emotional openness about loneliness, sadness, and hope.
Responds to Joyce's letter with interest and humor, writes back sincerely to learn about her life
Mentions he and Joyce have a lot in common and invites her to visit
Encourages Joyce to visit him, reassures her he won't make unwanted advances, offers to be anyone she wants him to be.
Refers to himself as 'a great guy' despite negative comic portrayals.
Shakes Joyce's hand upon meeting her in person.
Immediately tells Joyce he had a vasectomy, causing awkwardness and disbelief.
Shows concern by asking Joyce what’s wrong when he notices her unease.
Assumes Joyce should like the restaurant and feels disappointment when she doesn't.
Explains his vegetarianism is motivated by caring for his pet cat, implying empathy toward animals.
Responds to Joyce describing her health issues with 'Wow. Yer a sick woman, huh?'
Admits honestly to having serious cleanliness problems and shares a personal vulnerability.
Obeys Joyce's request to get water and aspirin without complaint, showing attentiveness and care.
Admits his dating insecurities and past hardships with women, expresses that despite problems Joyce seems like a great person.
Brings aspirin to Joyce and sits close to her, initiating a kiss after she invites him.
Shows concern and offers to help Joyce when she becomes ill, expressing that he feels terrible and wants to do something for her.
Expresses empathy and attempts to make Joyce comfortable despite his rusty dating skills.
Responds attentively to Joyce's discomfort and tries to help after she feels ill.
Admits his own flaws openly (rusty dating skills) but still proceeds confidently.
Overhears Joyce's request impatiently and apologizes promptly.
Despite the romantic moment, sensitively notices Joyce's unease and inquires about it.
Offers to make chamomile tea, stocks up on herbal teas considering Joyce's tastes.
Engages in tender conversation, expresses contentment being with Joyce.
Playfully asks Toby for fries and shares moment of lighthearted banter.
Shares personal news about his upcoming marriage openly in a casual conversation.
Reassures Joyce he will make room, asks for patience despite conflict over clutter.
Refuses to get rid of his records causing tension and frustration.
Slams door buzzer to unlock the front, inviting someone in.
Dismisses 'psychobabble crap' in conversation with Joyce.
Waves goodbye to Mr. Boats (ranting), showing casual politeness.
Leaves a friendly, excited voicemail for Joyce about a potential play.
Answers the phone and confidently shares news about a producer wanting to do a play about his life.
Slams the door buzzer to unlock the front door impatiently.
Engages in an argument with Joyce but dismisses psychological insight as 'psychobabble crap'.
Hysterically searches for a record album needed for a review due the next day, showing some urgency and responsibility toward his work.
Throws boxes of herbal teas at Joyce in frustration when she remains unresponsive and inactive, showing poor emotional control and ineffective problem-solving.
Ultimately just stands staring at Joyce without taking effective action to address the problem of her inactivity or his own frustrations.
Tries to cheer up Joyce and suggests going out to dinner despite her depression.
Gets frustrated and says 'I give up' after Joyce refuses his offers and doesn't respond.
Calls Joyce 'useless' for not answering the phone, showing impatience and irritation.
Tries multiple times to cheer up Joyce despite her depressive state.
Notices and retrieves important message from answering machine about TV appearance.
Frustrated and walks off saying 'I give up' when Joyce doesn't respond to his efforts.
Calls Joyce 'useless' for not picking up phone, showing impatience rather than problem-solving.
Models a wrinkled T-shirt for Joyce, shows casual disregard for appearance, interacts playfully with her as she cuts the shirt
Passes by a female business traveler in underwear carrying an ice bucket, accepts awkwardness without embarrassment
Backstage with Joyce prior to TV appearance, shares mildly cynical commentary with her, no hostility present
Jokes with Letterman about the price of the doll, showing a casual, easygoing demeanor and includes credit to his wife for making the doll.
Lets Letterman make fun of him on TV, accepts the situation with good humor, and appreciates the exposure.
Gives Letterman an earful right off the bat despite being his guest, showing bluntness and no pretense.
Muttered 'Fuckin' yuppie or whatever kinda freak you are' after MTV director reprimanded him.
Went over to say hello to his friend Toby on the MTV set despite the flashy environment.
Bumps into the MTV director and responds with a biting muttered insult.
Reflects insightfully on being coopted by corporations and the cultural dynamics of the 80s.
Smiles and acknowledges a fan recognizing him from the Letterman show.
Attempts to promote his comics by telling the yuppie to buy one, showing some sales effort.
Becomes defensive and insults the yuppie after a dismissive response, showing poor emotional control.
Expresses reluctance to travel or engage in activities outside his comfort zone, e.g., refuses to accompany Joyce to Jerusalem.
Yells at Joyce in public, attracting attention negatively and showing poor conflict management.
Yells at Joyce telling her to get a job, hurting her feelings.
Apologizes sheepishly to Joyce and grabs her hand after hurting her.
Carries Joyce's bags to the cab and expresses love before she leaves.
Yells at co-worker Miguel and demands the chart aggressively, causing offense.
Shows frustration and anguish alone, struggling with creative block, indicating vulnerability.
Raises hell on Letterman, aggressively criticizes him on air.
Responds defensively to Letterman's insults, engages in verbal sparring.
Expresses fear and hopelessness about illness, doubts his own strength, worries about who will care for Joyce.
Refuses Joyce’s suggestion to document illness to cope, says he just wants to die.
Puts his arm around Joyce, comforting her silently.
Appears miserable and dazed, does not express frustration outwardly beyond a brief 'Shit!' when locked out.
Retraces his steps to find his lost keys before requesting help.
Yells repeatedly and punches the door in frustration to get inside.
Critiques Fred's sketches thoughtfully and questions the wordiness, demonstrating awareness about storytelling clarity.
Appears disengaged or distracted while others play and work around him.
Joins Joyce and Fred in creating the book despite his illness, shows engagement with the project by looking it over and nodding.
Throws things around the house in anger due to his illness.
Struggles physically with his illness, unable to get out of the couch and weakly crawling up stairs.
Expresses delirium, desperation, and wishes to die while being physically weak and unresponsive.
Stands silently over Joyce in a trance-like or ghostly state, unable to communicate clearly or act decisively.
Internally questions his own existence and role as a character, reflecting deep self-doubt and confusion.
Delivers a formal, reflective soliloquy about his life and identity in a clear, structured manner.
Shows curiosity about the unusual occurrence of multiple Harvey Pekars in the same city, indicating an inquisitive and thoughtful mindset.
Passively observes his life passing before his eyes without taking immediate action or showing control over the situation.
Gives good news about his health to Joyce, showing vulnerability and allowing emotional openness.
Allows and accepts Danielle's affectionate hug after hearing positive news.
Watches Joyce and Danielle together, showing care and connection to family dynamics.
Though initially scared about Danielle living with them, accepts the decision recognizing her as a good kid and wanting a better life for her.
Takes in and raises a child not his own, treating her as family.
Engages playfully and sincerely with Danielle, encouraging her creativity and sharing his life openly.
Holds Danielle's hand to send her off to school, showing care and affection.
Responds to Danielle's mild criticism with wounded honesty, revealing vulnerability rather than defensiveness.
Shares personal stories through his comics and encourages Danielle to write about her own life.
Acknowledges his own imperfections and the mundane nature of his stories compared to others.
Holds Danielle’s hand tightly despite her discomfort, showing a lack of awareness of personal boundaries.
Waves and watches Danielle as the bus pulls away, showing a gentle, caring gesture
Acknowledges the ongoing struggles with family and work in a sincere and candid manner
Moves comic off desk to make space for cake, subtly demonstrating politeness and respect
Publishes a new edition of American Splendor themed 'Our Movie Year,' showcasing his experiences and work in the comic and film industry.
Stares at himself in the mirror, appears confused and sick, speaks deliriously about his identity as a character in a comic book, then collapses.
Is part of a group of children trick-or-treating but chooses not to wear a costume, looking irritated and removed from the group; spits and rolls his eyes at the housewife.
Displays irritation and disengagement by not participating in the Halloween dressing up, rolling his eyes, and spitting.
Shoves his hands in his pockets and remains removed from group activities, showing lack of social initiative.
Reluctantly participates in a film about his life for financial reasons, shows irritable and contrary behavior during recording.
Dismisses the importance of accuracy and control in the making of the film, downplays incidents like the Halloween event.
Displays self-awareness about his personal flaws and relationship failures, openly discusses his own lack of luck with women and quick marriages.
Persists in talking to the doctor despite his voice hurting and being asked to stop, showing lack of restraint and social awareness.
Attempts to explain his feelings and situation coherently while under physical distress, demonstrating some ability to communicate effectively.
Jumps off the exam table abruptly upon hearing bad news, indicating impulsivity rather than measured response.
Greets Mr. Boats politely despite being lost in thought.
Does not respond to the nurse's friendly address, being mentally distant.
Engages in a brief friendly exchange with Mr. Boats, showing some social connection.
Shows internal preoccupation and detachment, ignoring a friendly nurse.
Unselfconsciously accepts a derogatory caricature drawn by Crumb, showing self-awareness and lack of pretension.
Continues to read intently and focus on his interests despite the chaotic environment and Crumb's antics.
Appears slumped and disheveled, giving an impression of being unkempt and possibly unmotivated.
Shows a lack of confidence or social engagement as depicted in R. Crumb's later drawing of a tormented, isolated Harvey.
Shares personal struggles openly with Crumb despite feeling insecure and downtrodden.
Expresses bitterness about failed relationships and personal hardships without blaming others harshly or showing resentment.
Complains and whines in front of Crumb who appears indifferent; Harvey still continues to talk and share.
Engages thoughtfully and respectfully in conversation with Crumb, showing awareness of others' perspectives and realities.
Acknowledges Crumb's success realistically and without jealousy, demonstrating emotional intelligence.
Fails to carefully handle files at work resulting in knocking over a pile of important documents.
Responds to his work error with frustration but immediately assesses the situation by crouching down to survey the mess.
Carefully considers which checkout line to join, recognizing multiple factors involved in the decision.
Chooses to get behind an old lady known to be slow and argumentative at checkout, showing poor risk assessment given his impatience.
Displays impatience and frustration by rolling eyes and stamping foot when delay occurs, indicating lack of emotional control in the situation.
Responds to his inner cartoon alter ego's challenge by abruptly abandoning his grocery cart and rushing out of the supermarket, showing a sudden burst of motivation and decisiveness.
Begins story-boarding his first comic with stick figures despite limited artistic skill, demonstrating initiative and dedication to starting a creative project.
Works late into the night, dozing off over his scribbled comic pages but continuing to push forward, indicating perseverance and commitment.
Comic pages are crude and hastily drawn with stick figures and heavy writing, which may reflect limited skill or polish in execution.
Waits anxiously for Crumb's opinion, shows vulnerability and sincerity.
Expresses excitement and gratitude when Crumb offers to illustrate his work.
Initiates and develops original comic stories about real life, aiming to elevate the art form beyond typical genres.
Shows insecurity and self-doubt when receiving praise from Crumb, indicated by hesitant speech and unsure demeanor.
Expresses enthusiasm and openness to collaboration with Crumb, recognizing his own limitations in drawing and welcoming help.
Resigns himself to a menial existence to stave off desperation and feelings of uselessness.
Shows nervousness and self-doubt through scratching, tapping, and waking up in a cold sweat after a nightmare about his job.
Returns to writing despite internal struggles and unease.
Passively watches Toby steal files off shelves without intervening.
Questions religious practices and beliefs in a skeptical, dismissive manner.
Plans to inquire about lentils and Lent by asking a knowledgeable person (Sister Mary Fred).
Makes a sarcastic, somewhat self-deprecating remark about a nun's appearance and motives.
Responds to Toby's suggestion that he should believe in something bigger with defensiveness but does not engage meaningfully.
Explains to Actor Toby that nothing would have cheered him up at that point in his life because he was too lonely and depressed.
Sulks alone on a pedestrian bridge watching traffic pass below, feeling isolated despite some notoriety.
Walks on the shadowy side of the street while kids play and others smile around him.
Shows self-awareness about his loneliness and depression, acknowledging the limits of external comforts like gourmet jelly beans.
Despite growing notoriety from his comics, his personal life remains in shambles and he fails to find relief or confidence from increased attention.
Physically disheveled and emotionally burdened, displays a lack of energy and motivation, manifest in sulking and trudging through daily life.
Engages in thoughtful conversation about literature, showing intellectual curiosity and openness to new ideas.
Admits to not owning a car and walks despite being offered a ride, indicating modesty but possibly lack of initiative.
Expresses low self-esteem about romantic prospects but is honest and open about it, showing self-awareness but a lack of confidence.
Sits alone, deeply engrossed in a book, reflecting on life, feeling emotionally heavy but showing hope and determination to keep working.
Recognizes good handwriting on a fan letter and initiates a direct, personal correspondence by writing back to Joyce.
Engages in a casual, somewhat offhand conversation with Joyce, including asking personal questions and seemingly multitasking (writing while on bus, clipping toenails while talking).
Confidently invites Joyce to visit Cleveland, attempts to reassure her by highlighting his redeeming qualities despite self-deprecating comic portrayal.
Offers to accommodate Joyce during her visit and assures her he will respect her boundaries.
Acknowledges multiple artistic portrayals of himself and tries to explain and reframe a negative interpretation (Crumb's drawing) by rationalizing motion lines.
Promises to try to be anyone Joyce wants him to be, which may show adaptability but could also imply lack of authenticity or overpromising.
Acknowledges and discusses with Joyce about vasectomy decision calmly.
Approaches the day of his wedding floating on a cloud of happiness, showing emotional positivity.
Smoothly interacts with Toby, engaging in casual conversation and sharing food.
States upcoming travel and wedding plans confidently.
Quickly formed a relationship ('We met last week') but shows no signs of insecurity or indecision.
Asks probing questions about Toby's interests and tries to understand the significance of the movie to him.
Grabs the rest of Toby's fries and leaves without deeper engagement or reflection on Toby's feelings.
Engages in social interaction about the movie and personal life in a casual, somewhat self-aware manner.
Critiques the portrayal of 'nerds' in the movie with insight about socioeconomic realities and personal circumstances.
Dismisses the movie characters' reality without considering others’ feelings, causing social friction.
Shakes his head disappointedly at Toby's laughter, and criticizes Toby's daydreaming about movies being real.
Acknowledges his own harshness towards Toby, and reflects on his personal marital problems with some level of sincerity.
Refuses to part with his 78's records despite storage issues, showing reluctance to compromise or adapt quickly.
Paces nervously during conflict, indicating discomfort and lack of control in managing domestic issues.
Promises to make room eventually and admits he is not good at these kinds of things, showing some self-awareness but limited immediate problem-solving.
Enjoys a play that portrays his life, appreciates the artistic effort, and embraces the experience despite potential embarrassment.
Dismisses Joyce's hopes of having a family, insists on not wanting kids, ignores her attempts to communicate.
Admits honestly that he 'came clean' about his vasectomy when they first met; expresses self-awareness about his limitations.
Nervously taps his foot, worries about missing the bus and having to pay for a cab, shows anxiety rather than confidence.
Incorrectly assumes a bag is his and reacts frustrated when a Yuppie takes it, showing poor situational awareness and impulsiveness.
Ignores Joyce's attempt to communicate and dismisses important information about vasectomy reversibility, showing refusal to engage thoughtfully.
Openly admits his own limitations in caring for children and self-care, indicating self-awareness.
Firmly and clearly rejects an undesirable responsibility (having kids), displaying decisiveness.
Carries an ice bucket through a hotel hallway in underwear, seemingly unbothered by a passerby's stare.
Wears a wrinkled T-shirt for an outfit try-on and dismisses concerns about appearance with 'Who the hell cares?'
Changes into a slightly more formal outfit for a television appearance, showing some effort to be presentable.
Appears nervous and distracted backstage, pacing and commenting about being hungry instead of focusing on upcoming TV appearance.
Shows indifference or skepticism about the TV show’s popularity during the waiting period.
Asks the stage manager for food, showing vulnerability and a casual, open demeanor.
Tells Joyce to relax about the doll, indicating some impatience or brusqueness.
Turns to the host and initiates an offensive joke about Cleveland, taking Letterman off guard.
Answers questions about his work factually but patronizingly.
Appreciates Letterman's compliment about aiding the sick with sincere thanks.
Defensively explains why he maintains his day job, using self-deprecating humor to engage the audience.
Initiates offensive with host confidently, ready to engage with jokes and banter.
Responds with patronizing tone when asked if his stories are true, demonstrating confidence but possibly lacking tact.
Defends maintaining day job for financial stability despite writing success, showing practical awareness and self-knowledge.
Appears defensive about his writing career earnings in public, which could signal insecurity or lack of polished public relations skill.
Responds with cantankerous denial to Letterman's suggestion about selling his work.
Defends himself vigorously and truthfully when challenged on Letterman, managing to hold his own and earn audience respect and laughter.
Shows skepticism and guardedness when questioned about opportunities in show business, indicating possible distrust or insecurity about his professional standing.
Smiles and acknowledges the yuppie’s greeting politely.
Responds to the yuppie sarcastically and rudely after perceiving him as a jerk, calls him an 'asshole'.
Shows irritation and anger, yelling at Joyce in public.
Threatens Letterman regular after being insulted, clenches fists with hostility.
Engages in confrontational, politically charged banter on Letterman show.
Raises hell on Letterman, openly confronts and criticizes a popular TV host on air with sharp insults.
Refuses to heed warnings to change his approach or venue, ignores advice about appropriate contexts.
Maintains a strong, assertive stance despite social pushback and rejection.
Cuddles up against Joyce and expresses vulnerability by admitting he can't take being alone.
Shows emotional openness by admitting he will 'lose it' if Joyce goes away again.
Holds hands with Joyce in the hospital room, displaying fear and solidarity in a difficult moment.
Expresses disbelief and denial about his cancer diagnosis, showing emotional overwhelm and inability to focus on treatment plans.
Voices concerns about who will take care of his loved one if he dies, indicating awareness and care despite emotional difficulty.
Refuses to engage in a coping strategy proposed by Joyce to document his illness to gain control over the experience.
Admits to feeling not strong enough and wanting to give up, demonstrating low confidence and a lack of resilience.
Looks for keys but comes up empty, cannot get into his own apartment.
Continues to work and prepare for chemo treatment despite emotional and physical difficulty.
Pushes past elderly neighbor to get inside in frustration.
Yells repeatedly for Joyce to open the door in anger.
Looks away at Joyce and Danielle obliviously playing, showing some reflective or tender observation.
Requests Fred to bring his child along when he visits, showing concern for others despite his own struggles.
Joyce fights to keep Harvey focused on the project despite his illness.
Enraged Harvey throws things around the house.
Harvey depressed and struggling with his illness, showing vulnerability.
Harvey nods in agreement to the comic project idea while weak and incapacitated.
Harvey's inner turmoil and suffering displayed openly in the panels.
Joyce has her hand on him in the hospital waiting room, showing he has someone who cares deeply for him.
Expresses desire to die repeatedly and is emotionally withdrawn and silent when Joyce tries to engage him.
Asks Joyce deeply personal and vulnerable questions about his existence and identity.
Stands silently over a sleeping Joyce in a barely there, ghost-like state without interacting.
Expresses sadness and curiosity about other people named Harvey Pekar despite never having met them.
Lies passed out and delirious on the floor, seemingly isolated.
Reflects introspectively on the deaths of other men named Harvey Pekar and the meaning behind their shared name, showing thoughtful self-awareness.
Lays passed out and delirious on the floor, suggesting a period of vulnerability or lack of control.
Signs copies of 'Our Cancer Year' alongside Joyce, indicating active engagement and accomplishment in his creative work.
Writing freelance around the clock to pay bills despite chaos in life.
Acknowledges ongoing struggles and fights with spouse, managing a difficult family life.
Hunches over and walks alone down the busy street, symbolizing perseverance but also weariness.
Expresses realistic and pragmatic attitude toward aging and health, aiming to 'win a few skirmishes' despite inevitable decline.
Slumps at his desk flipping through a comic book at work.
